text: Elon Musk's startup XAI now valued at $24 billion after raising $6 billion in a fresh round of funding.
Adir Dabos is looking at some of the investors backing the tech billionaire in today's Tech Check.
Morning, Dee.
Hey, good morning, Carl.
So call them the Musk insiders.
As the Musk universe expands, a loyal group is emerging, and they're investors that are able to look past losses, reputational risk.
They continue to invest in his ventures.
Sequoia Capital, Andreessen Horowitz.
They were both part of the ex-AI $6 billion round.
They also chipped in $800 million and $400 million, respectively, for Musk's Twitter acquisition
Now, back then, Ben Horowitz tweeted, "'We invested because we believe in the co-founders
Evan Jack's vision to connect the world and we believe in Elon's brilliance to finally
make it what it was meant to be.'"
Since that tweet, the company, formerly known as Twitter, has lost billions of dollars in
value.
in in venture capital, that's a relatively short amount of time. And the attitude towards
failure here, it's generally far more accepting compared to many other business environments.

A CEO source operating in AI tells me that the ex research team is stellar and Musk will have access to special data sets with Twitter and Tesla Now the more interesting investor in this round and now firmly in the Musk insider circle
that may be Fidelity Management and Research Company, the investment advisor to Fidelity's
family of mutual funds.
It's the only institutional investor that was called out in that Series B XAI blog post
over the weekend.
Fidelity, of course, manages far more money than a typical VC fund, but it does so on behalf
of employees and retirees, endowments, insurance companies.
So they're getting a bit of this pie as well.
Fidelity put more than $315 million into Musk's AI takeover.
It was also part of a group that invested $1 billion in SpaceX, so firmly in that insider
circle.
There may also be newcomers to that group, like Tribe Capital, new to this round, according
to PitchBook.
And then there's a question of outsiders, guys, investors that have criticized Musk or
his ventures. The FT reports that some of them were frozen out of the ex-AI funding round.
And a separate source tells me that this was an allocation game at the end. Musk could basically
pick and choose who he wanted in this round. And even investors that were able to invest,
some of them would have invested more if they were able to.
